This should ensure  that the following stylesheet processing instruction is honored by  these new browser versions. For some more background you might want  to visit the following bug report:  https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=338621  --> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="/WebResource.axd?d=OG6ICBS3XdykvyL_wBngEtwfPZ1xqVL3SJbFznhjfEgbO7QCYjHbDfgdgnO_5IYl31FcIeZ2u_qHqs8zCgU_y6DDpKxLyAV4MxNJVxfxbqAA9wnJHfwytgbvEYfRnFp2CKySbJEfaqzaXNpSNK6oTGhGshY1&t=635319500310794128" media="screen"?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:content="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/" xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/">   <title>Archaeology</title>   <subtitle>Through archaeology we learn about our past by studying material remains. It covers the earliest period of human development to later prehistoric and historically documented societies.</subtitle>   <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology.aspx?RelatedItemsasStandardList_SyndicationType=2" />   <generator>Contensis: http://www.contentmanagement.co.uk</generator>   <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology.aspx?SyndicationType=2</id>   <updated>2015-03-06T08:16:30Z</updated>   <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology.aspx?SyndicationType=2" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml" />   <entry>     <title>Archaeology BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/ba-archaeology.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course aims to introduce you to the discipline of archaeology and to explain how archaeologists use evidence to interpret the past. You will progress from the first-year core modules to a more in-depth, scientific approach in the second and third years.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:39:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-04T15:57:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/ba-archaeology.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Archaeology BSc</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/bsc-archaeology.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>Archaeology bridges the sciences and humanities. During your BSc in Archaeology, you will develop your knowledge of the scientific techniques that archaeologists use to study ancient societies and learn to integrate scientific approaches with human perspectives on the past.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-04T15:53:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/bsc-archaeology.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Archaeology and History of Art BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology-history-of-art.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course offers the opportunity to explore the ways in which material culture and art are studied. You will explore the theory, methods and practice of archaeology and a range of archaeological periods and themes, while at the same time, fully examining aspects of Western art history and theory.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-04T15:44:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology-history-of-art.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Archaeology and Classical Civilisation BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/archaeology-classical-civilisation.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course offers the opportunity to combine a broad engagement with classical culture and society with learning archaeological skills and techniques, to enable first-hand study of material culture.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-05T10:10:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/archaeology-classical-civilisation.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Archaeology and Geography BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology-geography.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>On this course you will receive a balanced training in relevant aspects of physical, human, regional and technical geography. The archaeology modules provide a core understanding of archaeological method, environmental archaeology, ancient technologies, and the history of archaeological thought and research methods.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:35:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-04T15:29:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/archaeology-geography.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Ancient History and Archaeology BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/ancient-history-archaeology.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course emphasises both the common ground between ancient history and archaeology and the different approaches of the two disciplines. It is suited to those who wish to approach an understanding of the ancient world through both the material, literary and documentary evidence.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-05T10:09:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/ancient-history-archaeology.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Historical Archaeology BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/historical-archaeology-ba.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>Information on Historical Archaeology BA</summary>     <published>2014-07-04T12:57:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-04T16:04:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/archaeology/historical-archaeology-ba.aspx</id>   </entry> </feed>
